evidence.text: Houston police make hundreds of warrantless arrests every week.

extracted.value: Houston police make hundreds of warrantless arrests every week.

evidence.text: City of Houston arrests hundreds of people each week without a warrant.

extracted.value: City of Houston arrests hundreds of people each week without a warrant.

evidence.text: Misdemeanor and felony arrestees in City custody who do not post bail are eventually transferred to the Harris County Jail, where they receive probable cause hearings conducted by video.

extracted.value: Misdemeanor and felony arrestees in City custody who do not post bail are eventually transferred to the Harris County Jail, where they receive probable cause hearings conducted by video.

evidence.text: The City of Houston does not provide probable cause determinations for warrantless arrestees in its custody.

extracted.value: The City of Houston does not provide probable cause determinations for warrantless arrestees in its custody.

evidence.text: Probable cause determinations are provided only after an arrestee has been transferred to the Harris County Jail.

extracted.value: Probable cause determinations are provided only after an arrestee has been transferred to the Harris County Jail.

evidence.text: When it takes longer than 48 hours to transfer an arrestee to Harris County—and it often does—Houston continues to detain the arrestee unlawfully.

extracted.value: When it takes longer than 48 hours to transfer an arrestee to Harris County—and it often does—Houston continues to detain the arrestee unlawfully.

evidence.text: The City of Houston is not living up to its obligations to comply with the Fourth Amendment.

extracted.value: The City of Houston is not living up to its obligations to comply with the Fourth Amendment.

evidence.text: Houston has a policy and practice of disregarding this simple obligation.

extracted.value: Houston has a policy and practice of disregarding this simple obligation.

evidence.text: Whenever the Harris County Jail refuses to accept custody of an arrestee, or whenever Houston’s own arrest procedures are delayed, Houston continues to detain arrestees in its jail cells without probable cause rather than release them after 48 hours as the Constitution requires.

extracted.value: Whenever the Harris County Jail refuses to accept custody of an arrestee, or whenever Houston’s own arrest procedures are delayed, Houston continues to detain arrestees in its jail cells without probable cause rather than release them after 48 hours as the Constitution requires.

evidence.text: In July and August 2016 alone, there were hundreds of people arrested without a warrant who did not receive a probable cause determination within 48 hours but were still kept in City custody.

extracted.value: In July and August 2016 alone, there were hundreds of people arrested without a warrant who did not receive a probable cause determination within 48 hours but were still kept in City custody.

evidence.text: As a matter of policy and practice, the City does not release people who do not pay bail even if 48 hours or more have passed since their arrest.

extracted.value: As a matter of policy and practice, the City does not release people who do not pay bail even if 48 hours or more have passed since their arrest.

evidence.text: The Harris County Jail is notoriously overcrowded.

extracted.value: The Harris County Jail is notoriously overcrowded.

evidence.text: In July and August 2016, the overcrowding was so dire that the County told the Houston Police Department to stop transferring inmates to the County Jail, and refused to accept busloads of inmates from the Houston Jail.

extracted.value: In July and August 2016, the overcrowding was so dire that the County told the Houston Police Department to stop transferring inmates to the County Jail, and refused to accept busloads of inmates from the Houston Jail.

evidence.text: A spokesman for the Harris County Sheriff’s Office told the City that there was 'no room at the inn.'

extracted.value: A spokesman for the Harris County Sheriff’s Office told the City that there was 'no room at the inn.'

evidence.text: Booking records for 2016 show that in July and August alone, Houston held hundreds of inmates in its jail for longer than three days before transferring them to Harris County.

extracted.value: Booking records for 2016 show that in July and August alone, Houston held hundreds of inmates in its jail for longer than three days before transferring them to Harris County.

evidence.text: The large number of illegal detentions in July and August of 2016 reflects Houston’s broad, longstanding, and consistent policy of refusing to release warrantless arrestees even if more than 48 hours have passed since their warrantless arrest.

extracted.value: The large number of illegal detentions in July and August of 2016 reflects Houston’s broad, longstanding, and consistent policy of refusing to release warrantless arrestees even if more than 48 hours have passed since their warrantless arrest.

evidence.text: For example, booking records show that one person arrested on July 25, 2016, did not receive a probable cause determination until July 31, 2016 (more than 144 hours after arrest); another person, arrested on July 23, 2016, did not receive a probable cause determination until July 30, 2016 (more than 168 hours after arrest); and at least 35 other people in the months of July and August 2016 waited more than four days (96 hours) between arrest and a probable cause determination.

extracted.value: For example, booking records show that one person arrested on July 25, 2016, did not receive a probable cause determination until July 31, 2016 (more than 144 hours after arrest); another person, arrested on July 23, 2016, did not receive a probable cause determination until July 30, 2016 (more than 168 hours after arrest); and at least 35 other people in the months of July and August 2016 waited more than four days (96 hours) between arrest and a probable cause determination.

evidence.text: The City of Houston 'operates under a permanent injunction preventing it from detaining persons without a warrant for more than twenty-four hours without taking the person before a magistrate.'

extracted.value: The City of Houston 'operates under a permanent injunction preventing it from detaining persons without a warrant for more than twenty-four hours without taking the person before a magistrate.'

evidence.text: As a practical matter, there is no reason to delay probable cause determinations beyond 24 hours.

extracted.value: As a practical matter, there is no reason to delay probable cause determinations beyond 24 hours.

evidence.text: In June and July of 2016 alone, the City’s records show that the City of Houston confined hundreds of warrantless arrestees longer than 48 hours without a judicial determination of probable cause.

extracted.value: In June and July of 2016 alone, the City’s records show that the City of Houston confined hundreds of warrantless arrestees longer than 48 hours without a judicial determination of probable cause.

evidence.text: The City’s records show that violations occurred throughout 2016.

extracted.value: The City’s records show that violations occurred throughout 2016.

evidence.text: On January 7, 2016, at about 4:30 PM, Houston police officers arrested Juan Hernandez, without a warrant, for misdemeanor assault.

extracted.value: On January 7, 2016, at about 4:30 PM, Houston police officers arrested Juan Hernandez, without a warrant, for misdemeanor assault.

evidence.text: His arrest was entered into the City’s and Harris County’s electronic records at 4:53 PM.

extracted.value: His arrest was entered into the City’s and Harris County’s electronic records at 4:53 PM.

evidence.text: He was not brought before a judge until January 9, 2016, at 6:00 PM. He had been held over 49 hours without receiving a judicial determination of probable cause.

extracted.value: He was not brought before a judge until January 9, 2016, at 6:00 PM. He had been held over 49 hours without receiving a judicial determination of probable cause.

evidence.text: Five days after his hearing—after a week in custody—he pled guilty. He was released and given community supervision without jail time.

extracted.value: Five days after his hearing—after a week in custody—he pled guilty. He was released and given community supervision without jail time.

evidence.text: On January 7, 2016, at approximately 8:00 PM, Houston police officers arrested James Dossett, without a warrant, for possession of a controlled substance.

extracted.value: On January 7, 2016, at approximately 8:00 PM, Houston police officers arrested James Dossett, without a warrant, for possession of a controlled substance.

evidence.text: His arrest was entered at 8:10 PM.

extracted.value: His arrest was entered at 8:10 PM.

evidence.text: He was held until January 10, 2016, when transferred to Harris County Jail and received probable cause hearing at 4:00 AM.

extracted.value: He was held until January 10, 2016, when transferred to Harris County Jail and received probable cause hearing at 4:00 AM.

evidence.text: He had been held for 56 hours without receiving a probable cause hearing.

extracted.value: He had been held for 56 hours without receiving a probable cause hearing.

evidence.text: Two days after his probable cause hearing, on January 12, 2016, he posted bond and was released.

extracted.value: Two days after his probable cause hearing, on January 12, 2016, he posted bond and was released.

evidence.text: On April 22, 2016, Harris County dropped the charges.

extracted.value: On April 22, 2016, Harris County dropped the charges.
